questions.text: A 55 -year-old woman presents with rash over her lips as shown in image below, after she had taken NSAIDs for her joint pain. She had reported that she developed the same rash in the same location 5 months ago when she took the same drugs for back pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fixed Drug Eruption

 

Option C: Fixed Drug Eruption

 

The given clinical situation suggests a diagnosis of a Fixed drug eruption. Fixed drug eruption is one of the most common forms of drug induced exanthems

 

Fixed drug eruption (FDE)

 

FDE is a drug eruption distinguished by its recurrence at the same sites on re‚Äêchallenge, its short latency and benign nature, hence their site on the skin is fixed.

 

  • FDE typically presents 30 min to 8 h after drug exposure.
  • Typically, FDE presents as a sharply defined, round or oval erythematous and oedematous plaque which evolves to become dusky.
  • Violaceous and occasionally vesicular or bullous.
  • Classically hyperpigmentation occurs after lesions heal.

 

Most common cause:

 

  • NSAIDs - On Lips
  • Cotrimoxazole - On Genitals

 

Acute onset pigmentary changes after NSAID use point toward the diagnosis of FDE. NSAID's are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.

 

The majority of FDE is self-limiting with an excellent prognosis.

 

Note: The generalized bullous form of FDE should be differentiated from toxic epidermal necrolysis by prior similar history, absence of target lesions, and no involvement of mucosal surfaces.

 

The image below shows hyperpigmentation on the Lips & Glans penis developing simultaneously & healing at the same time frame.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chikungunya fever:

 

  • The nose and cheeks show signs of post-chikungunya hyperpigmentation on the Centro-facial face (so-called "chik sign").
  • After the fever has subsided, the pigmentary changes appear and could last for three to six months.
  • However, the question stem describes how pigmentary changes start to manifest after a few days.
  • Additionally, during the acute febrile phase, these patients will not experience any preceding erythema or eruption over the affected areas.

 

Option B. Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH)

 

  • This is an acquired form of hyper melanosis that develops as a result of cutaneous injury or inflammation, such as impetigo, atopic dermatitis, or acne vulgaris.

 

Option D. Drug hypersensitivity

 

  • This is an immune-mediated reaction to a drug of which symptoms ranging from mild to severe include rash, anaphylaxis, and serum sickness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fixed drug eruption by the recurrence of a localized rash at the same site upon re-exposure to an offending drug, such as NSAIDs.

 

Refs: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 118 Page No 118.12

choices.text: Cuffed Endotracheal Tube is not preferred due to chance of Tracheal Stenosis
Depth of Chest Compressions is equal to A-P diameter
First Shock Energy to be delivered is 3 J/kg
In Infants after Intubation Respiratory Rate should be 20-30 Breaths /min

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding Pediatric ACLS guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In Infants after Intubation Respiratory Rate should be 20-30 Breaths /min

 

Option D: Correct. After intubation in infants, the recommended Respiratory Rate to maintain Adequate Ventilation without over-ventilation is 20-30 Breaths per minute.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Incorrect. Current Pediatric Advanced Life Support (PALS) guidelines indicate the use of cuffed endotracheal tubes can be beneficial in pediatrics to ensure adequate ventilation and prevent aspiration, with proper sizing and cuff pressure monitoring to minimize the risk of tracheal injury.

 

Option B: Incorrect. The depth of chest compressions in pediatric patients should be at least one third the anteroposterior (A-P) diameter of the chest, not equal to it.

 

Option C: Incorrect. In pediatric advanced life support, the initial dose for defibrillation is 2 J/kg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Pediatric Advanced Life Support, it is recommended to use cuffed endotracheal tubes with careful monitoring, provide chest compressions at a depth of at least one third the A-P diameter of the chest, deliver the first defibrillation shock at 2-4 J/kg, and maintain a respiratory rate of 20-30 breaths per minute for infants post-intubation.

 

Ref: American Heart Association Basic Cardiovascular Life Support Provider Manual -2020 guidelines

questions.text: During an Anesthetic procedure, a 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension accidentally receives an intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone. Immediately after the injection, he reports severe pain at the injection site and the affected limb becomes pale. Which of the following is the most likely complication this patient is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ischemia

 

Explanation:-

 

Option A. Inadvertent intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone can lead to severe complications, the most likely of which in this patient is ischemia. This occurs because the injection of the drug directly into an artery can cause thrombosis, vasospasm, and a lack of blood flow to the affected limb, resulting in ischemia. The initial symptom is typically burning pain, and the affected limb may become pale due to vasospasm. This complication is commonly seen when thiopentone is injected in antecubital vein because in 10% of the case brachial artery divides above elbow giving a very superficial abnormal ulnar artery which lies deep to antecubital vein. Therefore, thiopentone injection should be avoided at antecubital fossa and it should be given in the veins over the outer aspect of forearm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inadvertent intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone can lead to complications such as ischemia, which can result in severe pain and pallor in the affected limb due to thrombosis and vasospasm. It is essential to avoid injecting Thiopentone into arteries to prevent this complication.

 

The management of intra-arterial injection of thiopentone includes –

 

  • Leaving Needle in situ in the Artery
  • Brachial Plexus Block (Stellate Ganglion Block)
  • Heparin Injection → To prevent Thrombosis.
  • Dilution of Thiopental by injection of Saline into the Artery
  • Papaverine or Prostacyclin injection – to relieve Spasm.
  • Urokinase, Streptokinase, Vasodilators, Steroid and Lignocaine can also be used in uncompensated Myocardial Disease.

 

 

REF: Miller's Anesthesia 9th edition • Page no. 832

questions.text: Match the following Genodermatoses in Column A with Associated Symptoms / Signs in Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d

 

Correct matches:

 

 

Explanation:

 

1. Neurofibromatosis-1 (c Crowe’s sign):

 

  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), also known as von Recklinghausen disease, can present with Crowe’s sign, which is axillary or inguinal freckling, one of the diagnostic criteria for NF1.

 

2. Sturge-Weber Syndrome (a Glaucoma):

 

  • Sturge-Weber syndrome is associated with glaucoma due to elevated episcleral venous pressure. It is a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by a facial port-wine stain, leptomeningeal angiomas, and ocular abnormalities.

 

3. Bourneville’s Disease (b Ash Leaf Macules):

 

  • Bourneville’s disease, also known as Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC), is associated with ash leaf macules, which are hypopigmented lesions typically found on the trunk and extremities.

 

4. Neurofibromatosis-2 (d Bilateral Acoustic Neuromas):

 

  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is associated with Bilateral Acoustic Neuromas (Vestibular Schwannomas), which are Benign Tumors that affect the nerve responsible for hearing and balance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genodermatosis with its associated symptom/sign: Neurofibromatosis-1 with Crowe’s sign, Sturge-Weber syndrome with glaucoma, Bourneville’s Disease with ash leaf macules, and Neurofibromatosis-2 with bilateral acoustic neuromas.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 73.2, 78.2, 80.3, 80.11

questions.text: This below given lesion may be described as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Discoid

 

Option B: A Discoid/Nummular (coin-like) lesion is what is depicted in the given image, which is a round lesion without a central clearing.

 

The centre and the edge are both equally coloured and active. Psoriasis and discoid eczema both exhibit it.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Annular lesions are ring shaped with central clearing i.e., only the edges are active & appear raised, or in different colour. It is present in granuloma annulare and tinea corporis.

 

 

Option C. Nodular - Nodular lesions are raised bumps that extend into the dermal layer or below. They can be associated with conditions like nodular melanoma.

 

Option D. Ecchymosis - This term refers to a large bruise, which is a purplish patch resulting from extravasation of blood into the skin, often after trauma.

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Annular lesions have a ring shape, discoid lesions are coin-like, nodular lesions are palpable and extend into the dermis or subcutis, and ecchymosis represents a larger area of hemorrhage into the skin.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume I Chapter 4. Page No 4.11, 4.13

choices.text: Bullous Pemphigoid
Dermatitis Herpetiformis
PUPPP
Pemphigoid Gestationis

questions.text: A 30-year-old female in her third trimester of pregnancy presents to the dermatology clinic with a 2-week history of itchy, tense blisters centralized on her abdomen, especially around the umbilical area. The blisters are on an erythematous base and she denies any prior history of similar lesions. She has no significant medical history and her pregnancy has been uneventful until these skin changes. Examination does not reveal involvement of the mucous membranes. Based on the clinical presentation, the most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigoid Gestationis

 

Option D.

 

Pemphigoid gestationis / Gestational pemphigoid / Herpes gestationis

 

  • This autoimmune blistering disorder occurs during pregnancy, typically in the second or third trimester, and is characterized by pruritic, tense blisters on the abdomen, often starting near the umbilicus.

 

 

  • It is associated with antibodies to BP180 and BP230, similar to bullous pemphigoid but is pregnancy specific.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid:

 

  • Incorrect because it typically affects older individuals and is not associated with pregnancy.

 

Option B. Dermatitis herpetiformis:

 

  • Incorrect because this condition presents with grouped vesicles and intense pruritus, often on extensor surfaces, and is associated with celiac disease.

 

Option C. PUPPP (Pruritic Urticarial Papules and Plaques of Pregnancy):

 

  • Incorrect because PUPPP usually presents with urticarial papules and plaques, starts in the stretch marks of the abdomen, and typically does not involve the formation of blisters.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigoid gestationis is a pruritic, vesiculobullous disorder of pregnancy presenting with tense blisters around the umbilical area, typically occurring in the second or third trimester, without mucosal involvement.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 115.13

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 472

questions.text: A 36-year-old female is posted for Modified radical mastectomy under general anesthesia. Halfway through the surgery, this is her capnograph. What should be the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repeat Muscle Relaxant

 

This capnograph shows a ‘Curare Cleft’

 

Option B: The ‘Curare Cleft’ is an indication that the patient is out of neuromuscular blockade and is making an attempt to breathe spontaneously. As they are halfway through the surgery, a top up dose of muscle relaxant needs to be given to paralyze the patient again.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Patient cannot be extubated as they are halfway through the surgery.
 

Option C: Deepening anaesthesia will not paralyze the patient.
 

Option D: Patient cannot be reversed from neuromuscular blockade as they are halfway through the surgery, surgery is not over.

 

Educational Objective:

In cases where the capnograph waveform shows a curare cleft in the capnograph during surgery, the appropriate next step may be to repeat the muscle relaxant to ensure adequate muscle paralysis for the procedure.

Uses of EtCO2:

A) It is the surest sign of Intubation

B) To diagnose a venous air embolism

C) To diagnose any circuit disconnections

D) To identify Bronchospasm intra-operatively

E)To diagnose Malignant Hyperthermia and exhausted soda lime

F) To monitor the performance of chest compressions in CPR

 

Ref:- Dorsch and Dorsch anesthesia equipment, 5th ed, pg 1016

questions.text: A 16-year-old with posterior fossa meningioma is being operated in the sitting position. There is a sudden drop in etCO2 and sudden hypotension intra-operatively. Venous air embolism is suspected. What is the most sensitive monitor to detect the same?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Trans Esophageal Echo (TEE)

 

Option C. TEE provides real-time imaging of the heart's chambers and valves. When venous air embolism is suspected, TEE can directly visualize air bubbles in the heart, especially in the right atrium, right ventricle, and pulmonary artery. It is not only sensitive but also allows for quantification of the volume of air and can guide therapeutic interventions if needed. For these reasons, TEE is considered the most sensitive monitor for detecting venous air embolism, especially in the scenario described.

 

Explanation:

 

While several methods can detect venous air embolism, Transesophageal echo (TEE) is considered the most sensitive and provides the most detailed information, making it the best choice in the given scenario.
Let's discuss each option:

 

Option A. Precordial Doppler: This is a non-invasive ultrasound technique that's used to detect venous air embolism. The Doppler probe is placed over the cardiac area (precordium) and can detect the movement of air bubbles in the bloodstream. It's relatively sensitive and can detect small volumes of air. However, it can't quantify the amount of air or localize its position.

 

Option B. Mill Wheel Murmur: This is a specific type of heart murmur associated with venous air embolism. It is caused by air bubbles passing through the right side of the heart and is characterized by a churning or "mill-wheel" sound. It is an audible sign detected using a stethoscope but is not the most sensitive method to detect venous air embolism.

 

Option D. End Tidal Nitrogen Levels: When room air (which contains a significant amount of nitrogen) enters the bloodstream, the nitrogen content of the exhaled air (end-tidal gas) can increase. Monitoring the end-tidal nitrogen levels can thus be an indirect way of detecting venous air embolism. However, this method is less commonly used in clinical settings because it's not as sensitive as other methods, and it requires specialized equipment

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the sitting position during neurosurgery, the mechanism of venous air embolism (VAE) primarily involves the potential entry of air through venous channels due to the patient's elevated head position. This elevation creates a gradient that allows air to be drawn into veins, leading to the formation of air emboli that can travel to the brain and cause neurological complications.

 

 

Ref:- Millers anaesthesia 9th ed pg 1879

choices.text: Morphine
Bupivacaine
Midazolam
Fentanyl

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly used as the drug of choice for spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bupivacaine

 

 

Option B. Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic that's often used for spinal anesthesia. It provides both sensory and motor blockage, making it suitable for a wide range of surgical procedures. Bupivacaine is known for its longer duration of action compared to other local anesthetics, making it a common choice for procedures requiring a longer period of anesthesia.

 

Explanation :

Option A. Morphine - This is an opioid medication that can be used as part of a spinal anesthesia regimen for its pain-relieving properties. However, it's typically used as an adjunct, not as the primary anesthetic agent.

 

Option C. Midazolam - Midazolam is a benzodiazepine, which is typically used for its sedative properties and is not typically used as the primary agent for spinal anesthesia.

 

Option D. Fentanyl - Like morphine, fentanyl is an opioid that can be used as part of a spinal anesthesia regimen for its analgesic properties. It is also used as an adjunct and not as the primary anesthetic agent for spinal anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:-

Bupivacaine is the drug of choice for spinal anesthesia due to its ability to provide prolonged sensory and motor blockade suitable for various surgical procedures."

 

Reference : Miller’s anesthesia 8th edition page 1043-1044

questions.text: Shortest acting non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mivacurium

 

Explanation:

 

Muscle Relaxants

Mivacurium is the only non-depolarizing blocker that is metabolized by plasma cholinesterase and is the shortest-acting muscle relaxant.

 

 

Educational Objective 

Long Acting: Pancuronium, Pipecuronium

Intermediate Acting: Atracurium,Cisatracurium.Vecuronium,Rocuronium

Short acting: Mivacurium Ultra-short acting: Gantacurium

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7th edition pg 366-406

choices.text: Post Tetanic Facilitation and Fade Absent
Train of Four Ratio > 0.4 but no Fade
Block is Reversed by Neostigmine
Fasciculation & Block potentiated by Volatile Anaesthetic Agents

questions.text: Which of the following statements about depolarizing neuromuscular blockade produced by succinylcholine is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Block is Reversed by Neostigmine

 

Option C. This statement is false. Succinylcholine-induced block is not reversed by neostigmine. Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, which is effective for reversing non-depolarizing (competitive) blocks but not depolarizing blocks.

 

Explanation:

 

Depolarizing neuromuscular blockade produced by succinylcholine has unique characteristics:

 

Option A. Post-Tetanic Facilitation and Fade Absent: In depolarizing blockade, post-tetanic potentiation or facilitation and fade are typically absent because the mechanism of blockade is persistent depolarization, not receptor competition or presynaptic inhibition of acetylcholine release.

 

Option B. Train of Four Ratio > 0.4 but No Fade: With succinylcholine-induced depolarizing blockade, the train of four (TOF) ratio can be greater than 0.4 without fade because the block is characterized by a persistent depolarization of the neuromuscular endplate, not an interference with acetylcholine binding as seen with non-depolarizing blockers.

 

Option D. Fasciculation & Block Potentiated by Volatile Anesthetic Agents: Volatile anesthetics are known to potentiate the effects of succinylcholine, leading to more pronounced fasciculations and a deeper neuromuscular block.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Venous Air Embolism

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with controlled thyrotoxicosis and Carcinoma rectum was undergoing laparoscopic abdominoperineal resection. Intra-operatively there was a sudden fall in blood pressure and heart rate. On examination, a mill-wheel murmur was heard. The end tidal CO2 was observed to reduce from 40 to 10. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Venous Air Embolism (VAE)

 

Option A: Venous Air Embolism (VAE) is a known complication during laparoscopic surgeries where the operative site is at a higher level than the heart. The classic signs of a sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2, hypotension, and the presence of a mill-wheel murmur (a splashing auscultatory sound heard over the heart due to the presence of gas in the cardiac chambers) support this diagnosis. The drop in end-tidal CO2 is due to a block in pulmonary blood flow by air, preventing CO2 exchange.

 

A patient undergoing laparoscopic/thoracoscopy or procedure (e.g., craniotomy) in sitting, head up, park-bench, knee-chest positions that place the operative site above the right atrium carry an increased risk of VAE. Sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2 concentration (ETCO2) sudden hypotension/circulatory arrest and Mill wheel murmur indicate the diagnosis.

 

Most sensitive monitor to detect VAE: - TEE (Trans-Esophageal Echocardiography).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Let's evaluate all the options for the scenario of a sudden fall in blood pressure and heart rate with a mill-wheel murmur and a significant drop in end-tidal CO2 during laparoscopic abdominoperineal resection:

 

Option B. A thyroid storm is a sudden exacerbation of thyrotoxicosis symptoms, which include tachycardia, hypertension, and hyperthermia, not typically a sudden fall in blood pressure and heart rate. There are no findings here that specifically suggest a thyroid storm.

 

Option C. Significant blood loss would lead to hypotension, but it would not explain the sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2 or the mill-wheel murmur, which are more indicative of air entering the venous system.

 

Option D. Acute hypoxia would likely cause an increase in heart rate as a compensatory mechanism and would not explain the mill-wheel murmur or the sudden drop in end-tidal CO2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely diagnosis in a patient experiencing sudden hypotension, bradycardia, a mill-wheel murmur, and a significant drop in end-tidal CO2 during a laparoscopic surgery in a position that places the operative site above the right atrium is venous air embolism (VAE).

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 5th Edition Pg 599, 600.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mycetoma

 

Option A.

 

  • Clinical image depicts swollen foot and multiple sinuses, which in the context of farmer, is consistent with a diagnosis of Mycetoma.

 

Mycetoma:

 

  • It is a chronic granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, which can extend to the underlying bone.
  • It typically presents in farmers or individuals who walk barefoot in endemic areas, with swollen feet and multiple sinuses that may discharge grains.

 

 

Option B. A Rodent ulcer

 

  • It is more commonly known as a basal cell carcinoma, typically presents as a skin lesion that may ulcerate but does not produce sinus tracts and granules.

 

Option C. Sporotrichosis

 

  • This is a fungal infection that typically presents as nodular lesions along lymphatic drainage, not typically with multiple sinuses and granules.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

 

  • This may present as a non-healing ulcer or nodule in sun-exposed areas but would not typically present with multiple draining sinuses and granules.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct diagnosis of mycetoma is based on the presentation of a swollen foot with multiple sinuses and granules, often associated with an occupational history of exposure to soil.
  • Recognizing this presentation is important for the management and initiation of appropriate antimicrobial therapy.Top of FormBottom of Form

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 32.73

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1350

choices.text: HPV 2 is the most common causative organism in common warts
Deep palmoplantar warts are also called as Myrmecia warts
HPV 6 is the most common causative organism in anogenital warts

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding Warts and its management except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cryotherapy is a painless procedure

 

Option D.

 

The main disadvantage of Cryotherapy / Freezing is pain.

 

Cryogun has the freezing agent:

 

 

Below image depicts Cryotherapy being administered:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Verruca vulgaris or common wart is most commonly caused by human papillomavirus-2 (HPV-2) but is also related to types 1, 4, 27, and 57.

 

Below image depicts Verruca vulgaris:

 

 

  • Common warts typically have no symptoms.
  • They appear as firm papules with a rough horny surface and exhibit acanthosis, hyperkeratosis, and papillomatosis.
  • The hands, fingers, and knees of young children are the areas that are most frequently affected.
  • Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon may be observed.

 

Option B: Deep palmoplantar warts are also called Myrmecia warts.

 

  • It is usually caused by human papillomavirus-1 (HPV-1).
  • The superficial form of plantar warts is called mosaic warts which are caused by HPV-2.

 

Below image depicts Plantar warts

 

 

Various types of warts and their clinical features:

 

  • Verrucous warts present as asymptomatic skin-coloured papules and plaques with rough surfaces.
  • Filiform warts are finger-like projections.

 

 

  • Verruca Plana are flat surfaced lesions and hence the name. They are mainly due to HPV-3 and - 10.

 

 

Option C: Anogenital Warts are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus 6 (HPV-6 > HPV-11).

 

 

Educational Objective: 

Cryotherapy:

 

  • A doctor administers this treatment.
  • Liquid nitrogen, carbon dioxide snow, and dimethyl ether can all cause thermal injury to the skin.
  • The coldest freeze is produced by liquid nitrogen, which is frequently employed in practice.
  • A cotton wool bud or a cryospray is used to apply it until a rim of iced tissue forms around the wart (visible as a white discoloration).
  • Depending on the size and location of the wart, the freezing is maintained for 5 to 30 seconds.
  • With freezing times under 30 seconds, scarring is unlikely.
  • Cryotherapy is safer than imiquimod, podophyllin, and podofilox, which are teratogenic& so contraindicated during pregnancy.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th editionPage no 25.43, 25.47, 25.48, 25.52

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no1214

Andrew's Diseases of the Skin: Clinical Dermatology - 11th Edition Chapter 19, Page no 401

choices.text: Bullous impetigo is the other name for this disease
Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism
Golden yellow or honey-coloured crusts are seen associated with this disease
Superficial intraepidermal bulla are formed as desmoglein-1 is targeted by the exfoliative toxins

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents to the clinic with several fluid-filled blisters on the skin and some areas with a varnish-coloured crust. The infant does not appear to be in significant discomfort, and the rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Given the clinical presentation and the age of the infant, which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Golden yellow- or honey-coloured crusts are seen associated with this disease

The clinical picture described‚Äîa 2-month-old infant with fluid-filled blisters and varnish coloured crusts‚Äîis classic for bullous impetigo, a localized superficial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus. The exfoliative toxins released by the bacteria specifically target desmoglein-1 of the epidermis. This results in the formation of superficial intraepidermal bullae that rupture easily, leaving a varnish-like crust, rather than the golden yellow or honey-coloured crusts that are seen in non-bullous impetigo.

Other options:

  • A. Bullous impetigo is the other name for this disease:
    This is a true and appropriate statement. The condition described aligns with the presentation of bullous impetigo, and it is correctly named as such.
  • B. Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism:
    Accurate. The organism Staphylococcus aureus is responsible for bullous impetigo, owing to its production of exfoliative toxins.

  • D. Superficial intraepidermal bulla are formed as desmoglein-1 is targeted by the exfoliative toxins:
    This is a correct pathophysiological mechanism explaining how the bullae form in this condition. 

     

Pemphigus neonatorum / Bullous impetigo:

 

  • It is the most likely diagnosis from the given clinical case scenario.

  • It is caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

  • Impetigo is a contagious, superficial pyogenic infection of the skin.

  • Superficial intraepidermal bulla are formed as desmoglein-1 is targeted by the exfoliative toxins produced by S. aureus.

  • After the bulla rupture, they leave behind varnish crust (NOT Golden yellow or honey-coloured crusts).

  • Below image depicts Bullous Impetigo with intact bullae & Varnish coloured crusts.

  • Hypopyon Sign - The pus gravitates to the lower half of the bulla. 

 

 

Complication:

 

Hematogenous spread of Exfoliative toxin can lead to Ritter's disease/Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS).

 

Impetigo management:

 

  • Treatment involves topical Fucidin or mupirocin, retapamulin in resistant cases.

  • Systemic therapy with flucloxacillin and erythromycin may be given.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus neonatorum, or bullous impetigo, typically presents with varnish-like crusts rather than golden yellow or honey-colored crusts after bullae rupture.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition

Chapter 26, Page nos 26.14-26.15

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male patient from Bihar with Normo-Anesthetic Hypopigmented Lesions and a History of Prolonged Fever in Childhood, what is the probable clinical diagnosis, considering the Absence of Thickened Nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis.

 

Option D.

 

  • The case scenario suggests a diagnosis of Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis.

 

Post- Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis:

 

  • Occurs 1-5 years after Kala azar in untreated or incompletely treated cases. Manifests as nodules over exposed areas (Face), Hypopigmented macules over trunk and photosensitivity.

  • The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously.

 

 

Important differential for PKDL is Lepromatous leprosy:

 

 

 

Drug of choice for:

 

  • Kala azar - Liposomal Amphotericin B

  • PKDL - Miltefosine

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tuberculoid leprosy:

 

  • This form of leprosy presents with hypopigmented patches with well-defined borders.

  • However, it is typically associated with thickened nerves, which is absent in the patient described.

 

Option B. Lepromatous leprosy:

 

  • This is a more advanced and disseminated form of leprosy with multiple nodules, plaques, and thickened nerves.

  • It doesn't fit the presentation described.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

  • It is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.

  • The initial presentation can be patches, which might resemble the described lesions, but the history of prolonged fever in childhood and the geographic location (Bihar) make PKDL more probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PKDL is a probable diagnosis in a patient with a history of prolonged fever in childhood presenting with normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesions without any thickened nerves, especially from the Bihar region.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 33.50-33.51, 140.10

choices.text: Underlying principle is a Cell-Mediated Immunity
It is associated with severe burning rather than Itching
Memory T Cells are involved
Patch Test can confirm the diagnosis once the Acute Phase is managed

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the ENT outpatient department for a routine dressing. Shortly after the dressing is applied, he develops an erythematous and oozing reaction around his ear, as shown in the accompanying image. The patient denies previous similar reactions. The dressing material contained povidone-iodine, which the patient has been exposed for the first time now. What is TRUE about the patient's reaction to the dressing change?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is associated with severe burning rather than Itching

 

Option B:

 

  • The patient's symptoms are consistent with irritant contact dermatitis (ICD), which is a non-allergic reaction to a chemical irritant, in this case, povidone-iodine. ICD is characterized more by a burning sensation rather than itching, which is more typical of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD).

 

 

Explanation:


Option A. The underlying principle is cell-mediated immunity - Incorrect.

 

  • This would be true for allergic contact dermatitis, not irritant contact dermatitis, which is a non-immune direct toxic effect of the irritant on the skin.

 

Option C. Memory T cells are involved - Incorrect.

 

  • Memory T cells are involved in allergic reactions, not in the non-immunologic reactions of ICD.

 

Option D. Patch testing can confirm the diagnosis once the acute phase is managed - Incorrect.

 

  • Patch testing is used to diagnose allergic contact dermatitis, not ICD.
  • However, it may still be used if an allergic component is suspected after the acute phase of ICD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To distinguish between irritant contact dermatitis and allergic contact dermatitis based on symptoms and underlying mechanisms. ICD is characterized by a burning sensation and results from direct toxicity, not an immune-mediated response.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 129.3

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 268

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.text:
Assertion: General Anaesthesia is the preferred technique of anaesthesia in emergency obstetric surgeries. 

 

Reason: General anesthesia is more comfortable for parturients who have fear of needles or surgery.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion

 

Explanation:

 

General anaesthesia is the preferred technique of anaesthesia in emergency obstetric surgeries because it has a rapid and reliable onset and provides good control over the airway and ventilation. There are also less chances of hypotension as compared to neuraxial blockade.

 

Disadvantages of general anaesthesia in obstetrics:

 

  • Use of multiple drugs that cross uteroplacental barrier
  • Difficult airway in obstetrics
  • Risk of aspiration is increased in parturient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

General anesthesia is often the choice for emergency obstetric surgeries due to its rapid onset and control of airway and ventilation, not primarily because of patient comfort concerns regarding needle phobia or fear of surgery.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology 5th Edition Pg 855

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps to be performed in correct sequence for OHCA (out-of-hospital cardiac arrest) chain of survival guidelines?

 

  1. Advanced Life Support
  2. Early CPR
  3. Activation of Emergency Response System
  4. Rapid Defibrillation
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C, B, D, A

 

Explanation:

 

Chain of survival:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 6 links in the adult out-of-hospital Chain of Survival are:

 

  • Recognition of cardiac arrest and activation of the emergency response system
  • Early cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) with an emphasis on chest compressions
  • Rapid defibrillation
  • Basic and advanced emergency medical services
  • Advanced life support and post-cardiac arrest care
  • Emotional Recovery

 

A strong Chain of Survival can improve chances of survival and recovery for victims of cardiac arrest.

Disability free life expectancy
Average life expectancy
Expectation of life at 1 year of age

questions.text: Which of the following index refers to Sullivan’s index?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Disability free life expectancy

 

Explanation:

 

Sullivan’s indicator is a health state measure of a group of persons which is independent of its age structure.

 

Sullivan’s Index, now called DFLE (Disability-free life expectancy), means the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability (given the current mortality and disability). It is calculated as Life expectancy minus duration of disability

 

Educational Objective:

 

DFLE = Sullivan's Index

 

Ref: Textbook of Community medicine, AH Suryakantha, 4th ed, pg10.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is conducting a workshop for medical students on disease progression and diagnosis. During the session, she uses the metaphor of an iceberg to explain the prevalence of certain diseases within the community. While the tip of the iceberg represents those cases that are overt and diagnosed, the submerged part denotes those not readily visible or diagnosed. The submerged portion is often much larger and represents a significant part of the affected population. Which of the following does NOT accurately characterize this submerged portion of the iceberg metaphor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Diagnosed cases under treatment

 

Explanation:

 

  • Iceberg Phenomenon of disease: Disease in a community may be compared to an iceberg
    • Floating tip is what physician sees in community, i.e.,clinical cases
    • Vast submerged portion of iceberg represents hidden mass of disease, i.e., latent, inapparent, presymptomatic and undiagnosed cases and carriers in community
    • Line of demarcation (water surface): Is between apparent and inapparent infections
    • Water surrounding iceberg: Healthy population

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ‘Epidemiologist is concerned with Hidden portion of iceberg’ whereas Clinician is concerned with Tip of iceberg
  • ‘Screening is done for Hidden portion of Iceberg’ whereas diagnosis is done for tip of iceberg
  • Iceberg phenomenon of disease is not shown by:
    • Rabies
    • Tetanus
    • Measles
    • Rubella

 

 

Ref: Park 27th ed, pg 46

questions.text: A public health physician is managing a recent outbreak of cholera in a coastal community. One of the patients, a 40-year-old man, has recently recovered from a severe case of cholera. Despite clinical recovery, follow-up testing reveals that he is still excreting Vibrio cholerae in his stool. This information is critical for the public health team in understanding the dynamics of disease transmission post-recovery. The physician needs to categorize this patient correctly in terms of carrier status to inform further public health actions. In the context of a cholera outbreak, how should the public health physician categorize a patient who continues to excrete Vibrio cholerae in his stool 2 to 3 weeks after clinical recovery?
questions.solution:
Ans.  C. Convalescent carrier

 

Option C.

 

CONVALESCENT CARRIER: The patient who has recovered from an attack of cholera may continue to excrete vibrios, during his convalescence for 2-3 weeks. A convalescent state has been found to occur in patients who have not received effective antibiotic treatment. The convalescent carriers can often become chronic or long-term carriers. Example - Typhoid, Bacillary Dysentery, Amoebic Dysentery, Cholera, Diphtheria & Pertussis (Clinical recovery does not coincide with bacteriological recovery)

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Chronic carrier:  Excretes infectious agents for indefinite periods (> 6 months). Example - Typhoid, Hepatitis-B, Dysentery, Meningococcal Meningitis, Malaria, Gonorrhoea, etc.

 

Option B. Contact carrier: Carrier who gets infected from a case.

 

Option D. Incubatory carrier: Shed infectious agent during incubation period of disease. Example - Measles, Mumps, Polio, Pertussis, Influenza, Diphtheria, Hepatitis-B

 

Educational Objective:

 

Convalescent Carriers: Shed the disease agent during the period of Convalescence, e.g. Typhoid, Bacillary Dysentery, Amoebic Dysentery, Cholera, Diphtheria & Pertussis (Clinical recovery does not coincide with bacteriological recovery)

 

Different types of carriers of a disease

 

 

Reference: Park 26th edition (page 267)

questions.text: During an infectious disease rotation, a medical resident is consulted about a patient who is identified as a carrier of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, the bacterium responsible for diphtheria. While the patient is asymptomatic, the resident understands the importance of treating carriers to prevent the spread of the infection. The resident discusses with the supervising physician about the appropriate pharmacological intervention for carriers of diphtheria. What is the recommended drug for treating carriers of diphtheria?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Erythromycin

 

Option B:

 

The carriers of Diphtheria should be treated with 10 days course of oral erythromycin, which is the most effective drug for the treatment of carriers. This antibiotic is effective in eliminating the bacterium from the nasopharynx, thereby reducing the risk of transmission.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Penicillin:  can be used as DOC for treating Diphtheria Cases not carriers.

 

Option C. Doxycycline:  Drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis for Malaria, if needed for <6 weeks (not for diphtheria)

 

Option D. Rifampicin:  Drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis for Meningococcal meningitis (not for diphtheria)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug of Choice in Diphtheria:-

        

 

Drugs for Chemoprophylaxis:

 

                   

 

Ref: Park 26th edition (page 177)

questions.text: In a town having a population of 200,000 at midyear, 2,200 individuals were reported to have diabetes mellitus on January 1, 2022. Throughout that year, 450 new cases were diagnosed, and 75 individuals with diabetes mellitus passed away due to complications. Based on this information, calculate the point prevalence of diabetes mellitus in the town as of December 31, 2022.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 12.87 per 1000

 

Option B:

 

 Point prevalence of a disease is defined as the number of all current cases (old and new) of a disease at one point in time, in relation to a defined population.

 

Point prevalence (in percentage) is given by the formula:

 

                                ‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã    ‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã    ‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

 

 

Point prevalence of diabetes mellitus on 31.12.2022

 

= {(2200-75) + 450} x 100 /(200000-75)

 

= 2575 x 100/ 199925

 

= 1.287 per 100

 

But, the options are in per 1000 population, so the answer is 12.87/1000 population

 

Educational Objective:

 

Point Prevalence is defined as Number of total cases at a given point of time


Period prevalence is defined by Number of total cases in a given year‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

questions.text: In a study evaluating ELISA as a screening test for HIV, where PCR was used as the confirmatory diagnostic test, it was found that ELISA was positive in 90 out of 100 confirmed HIV patients. Additionally, ELISA showed positive results in 11 out of 100 individuals without HIV. Based on this information, what are the positive predictive value (PPV) and negative predictive value (NPV) of the ELISA test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 89.1% and 89.9%

 

Explanation:

 

 

  • Positive predictive value of the test= True positive/ Total positives = 90*100/101= 89.1%
  • Negative predictive value= True negatives/ Total negatives = 89*100/ 99= 89.9%

 

Some important Pointers - 

 

  • If prevalence of disease increases, predictive value of a positive test will - Increase
  • PPV of a screening test is directly proportional to prevalence of disease in the population

 

 

 

  • Diagnostic power of a screening test: Predictive accuracy
    • Diagnostic power of a screening test to correctly identify a disease: Positive predictive value (PPV)

 

 

‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

 

  • Diagnostic power of a screening test to correctly exclude a disease: Negative predictive value (NPV)

 

 

 

  • Predictive value of a screening test depends on ‚Äì Sensitivity; Specificity; Prevalence of disease in the population
  • PPV is also known as ‚Äòpost-test probability of a disease‚Äô or ‚Äòprecision rate‚Äô

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Positive predictive value of the test= True positive/ Total positives 
  • Negative predictive value= True negatives/ Total negatives
  • Predictive value of a screening test depends on ‚Äì Sensitivity; Specificity; Prevalence of disease in the population

 

Ref: park 26th ed pg.

questions.text: A public health official is analyzing a population's reproductive health programs and aiming to reach a Net Reproduction Rate (NRR) of 1. At what level must the Couple Protection Rate (CPR) be set to achieve an NRR of 1?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 60%

 

Explanation:

 

Couple Protection Rate (CPR) - It is an indicator of the prevalence of contraceptive practice in the community.

 

NRR = 1 can be achieved only if the CPR > 60%

 

Value of NRR = 1 is equivalent to 2-child norm. This goal of NRR was to be achieved by 2017.

 

Net reproduction rate (NRR): Expected number of daughters, per newborn prospective mother, who may or may not survive to and through the ages of childbearing. 

 

Replacement level of fertility (TFR = 2.1, i.e. NRR = 1): TFR at which newborn girls would have an average of exactly 1 daughter over their lifetimes (women have just enough babies to replace themselves). This is also known as ‚ÄòAdequate level‚Äô

 

CPR is percent of eligible couples (ECs) protected against one or the other approved methods of family planning, viz. condoms, OCPs, IUDs, sterilization

 

Effective Couple Protection Rate (ECPR) ‚Äì ECPR is the percent of eligible couples (ECs) protected against one or the other approved methods of family planning, viz. condoms, OCPs, IUDs, sterilization, taking into account their effectivity

 

 

                   

 

Effectivity of approved contraceptive methods - 

 

1. Condoms: 50%
 

2. IUDs: 95%
 

3. OCPs: 100%
 

4. Sterilization (Vasectomy or Tubectomy): 100%

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Achieving a Net Reproduction Rate (NRR) of 1 generally requires a high Couple Protection Rate (CPR) > 60%

 

Ref. Park 23/e pg. 493, 27/e pg. 567

questions.text: A 25-year-old man and his 23-year-old partner, a couple with no current desire for pregnancy, visit your clinic for contraception counseling. They have been using male condoms as their primary method of contraception but express concern about the potential for failure and unintended pregnancy. They inquire about the average failure rate among users. What is the average failure rate associated with male condom use among typical users?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 14

 

Explanation:

 

Failure rates for the condom vary enormously.

 

Surveys have reported pregnancy rates varying from 2-3 per 100 women years to more than 14 in typical users.

 

Most failures are due to incorrect use.

 

Pearl Index

 

Pearl Index is Failures per 100 women-years of exposure. Pearl Index Is normally used for studying the Failure rate/ Efficacy of contraceptive

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pearl Index Male condom - 2-14 per HWY 

 

Pearl Index Female condom - 5-21 per HWY 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 575

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, who is a mother of two healthy children, comes to your outpatient department expressing a desire for permanent sterilization. She asks about the age criteria for undergoing the procedure. What are the lower and upper age limits recommended for a woman to undergo sterilization if she fulfills all other criteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 22 and 49 years.

 

Explanation:

 

New Sterilization Guidelines in India 2014

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lower and upper age limits recommended for a woman to undergo sterilization if she fulfills all other criteria - 22 and 49 years of age. 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 589.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to your clinic with joint pain, a recent history of sore throat, and unusual involuntary movements. Based on her presentation, you suspect rheumatic fever and review the major criteria for its diagnosis according to the Jones criteria. Which of the following is NOT considered a major criterion in the diagnosis of rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Polyarthralgia

 

Explanation:

 

Polyarthalgia is a minor criterion, rest all 3 other options are Major criteria

 

Revised Jones Criteria

 

Major criteria ‚Äì carditis, polyarthritis, chorea, erythema marginatum, subcutaneous nodule

 

Minor Criteria- clinical; fever, polyarthralgia, laboratory; elevated acute phase reactants (erythrocyte sedimentation rate or leukocyte count)

 

Supporting evidence of a preceding streptococcal infection within 45 days - electrocardiogram; prolonged PR interval, elevated or rising antistreptolysin-0 or other streptococcal antibody, or a positive throat culture, or rapid antigen test for group A streptococcus, or recent scarlet fever.

 

NEW Revised Jones Criteria

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polyarthralgia is considered a minor criterion in the diagnosis of rheumatic fever according to the Jones criteria, whereas chorea, pancarditis (as part of carditis), and subcutaneous nodules are major criteria.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed, pg 427.

choices.text: Low birth weight babies
Small for date babies

questions.text: A term neonate is evaluated in the newborn nursery for being significantly smaller than other babies at the same gestational age. The pediatric resident notes that the baby's birth weight is below the 10th percentile for their age. This finding suggests that the neonate experienced a delay in growth while in the uterus. What term is used to describe neonates born with such a condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Small for date babies

 

Explanation: 

 

Small-for-date babies may be born at term or preterm. They weigh less than the 10th percentile for the gestational age. These babies are the result of retarded intrauterine fetal growth.

 

Small-for-date (SFD) babies: Born at term or post-term 

 

  • weigh ‘less than 10th percentile for gestational age’
  • as a result of IUGR
  • high risk of dying in neonatal and infancy period

 

Pre-term babies: Born at <37 weeks POG

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Small-for-date (SFD) babies born at term or post-term, but weigh ‘less than 10th percentile for gestational age’ and as a result of IUGR

 

Ref: Park 26th edition (page 619)

questions.text: A medical resident is studying the effects of various natural toxins on human health. Match the following toxins with the diseases they are commonly associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans.  D. a- ii, b- i, c-iii

 

Explanation:

 

The cause of Nuerolathyrism is a toxin, Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) which is found in the seeds of the pulse, L.sativus (Khesari dhal).

 

Epidemic dropsy- sanguinarine from argemone oil This toxic substance interferes with the oxidation of pyruvic acid which accumulates in the blood.

 

Endemic ascites- pyrrolizidine alkaloids in Jhunjhunia seeds were found to be hepatotoxins.

                                

Lathyrism - Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‚ÄòKhesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)‚Äô. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism. Toxin is present in lathyrus seeds is Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA). It manifests as following stages: Latent stage; No-stick stage; One-stick stage; Two-stick stage and Crawler stage.

 

Interventions for prevention and control of lathyrism:

 

  • Vitamin C prophylaxis
  • Banning the crop
  • Removal of toxin: Steeping method and Parboiling
  • Education
  • Genetic approach
  • Socio-economic changes

 

Epidemic Dropsy ‚Äì This is caused by contamination of mustard oil with ‚ÄòArgemone oil‚Äô. Toxin ‚ÄòSanguinarine‚Äô is contained in argemone oil. It may lead to sudden noninflammatory edema of bilateral lower limbs, diarrhea, dyspnoea, cardiac failure and death; It can also lead to glaucoma; It may sometimes manifest as ‚ÄòSarcoids‚Äô (dilatation of skin capillaries). Epidemic dropsy may occur in all ages except breast-fed infants.‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã Edema in Epidemic dropsy occurs due to proteinuria (specifically loss of albumin).


Argemone oil may be detected by following tests: 

 

  • Nitric acid test
  • Paper chromatography test: Most sensitive test

 

Endemic Ascites: 


                    Toxin: Pyrrolizidine alkaloids (Hepatotoxins)
                    Adulterant: Crotalaria plant (Jhunjhunia)

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Park 26th edition (page 746, 747)

questions.text: Dr. Ramesh, a community medicine specialist, is giving a lecture on understanding the determinants of health to a group of medical students. During the session, he emphasized the importance of understanding human history, including the physical, social, and cultural evolution of humans, as it often shapes many health behaviors and practices observed in different communities. A curious medical student asks about the specific term that refers to this study. Which of the following terms best describes the study of the physical, social and cultural history of humans?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anthropology

 

Option D:

 

Social anthropology is a branch of anthropology that centers on the examination of human societies and cultures. It places significant emphasis on understanding social structures, relationships, customs, beliefs and practices that shape the diverse aspects of human social life.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sociology: Sociology is the scientific study of human society, social interactions, and the patterns of behavior that emerge from these interactions. It is a discipline that examines the structure, development and functioning of human societies, as well as the individuals and groups that constitute them.

 

Option B. Social Structure: The various elements of social structure such as social institutions (e.g., family, education, religion, government), social hierarchies (e.g., social class, race, gender), and social norms (e.g., customs, values, rules).

 

Option C. Medical Sociology: Medical sociology is a specialized branch of sociology that focuses on the social aspects of health, illness, healthcare systems and the interaction between society and medicine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The role of social anthropology in health sciences. It offers a comprehensive view of how human history, including physical, social and cultural evolution, shapes health behaviors and practices in different communities, thus aiding medical professionals in developing culturally sensitive health interventions and understanding the diverse health needs of various populations.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed, pg 760.

choices.text: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection

questions.text: A 40-year-old sexually active male presents to an STD clinic with painful genital sores as shown in the image below. He reports that the lesion appeared about two weeks ago and has been progressively worsening. On examination, you observe multiple painful bleeding ulcers with unilateral unilocular painful suppurative inguinal bubo. There are no other visible lesions, and the patient denies any systemic symptoms. He had multiple sexual partners in recent months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chancroid (Soft chancre)

 

OPTION C:

 

Chancroid (Soft chancre):

 

  • Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It presents with painful genital ulcers and painful suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo), as described in the scenario.
  • The ulcers are often described as "soft" (as opposed to the "hard" chancre of syphilis) and can bleed easily.
  • This fits the patient's presentation perfectly.

 

Explanation:

 

OPTION A: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection:

 

  • HSV typically presents as painful vesicles that can rupture to form ulcers.
  • The key difference is that the inguinal lymphadenopathy seen in HSV (if present) is typically bilateral and not as dramatically painful or suppurative as that in chancroid.

 

Differentiating features between Herpes genitalis & Chancroid:
 

 

  • Moreover, the course of the lesion and the presence of multiple painful ulcers fit chancroid better than HSV.

 

OPTION B: Syphilis (Primary Stage):

 

  • The primary lesion of syphilis is the chancre, which is a solitary, painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders.
  • The patient's presentation of multiple painful ulcers with a painful inguinal bubo does not fit the primary syphilis picture.

 

OPTION D: Donovanosis (Granuloma inguinale):

 

  • Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, donovanosis typically presents as painless, beefy-red ulcers that bleed easily. They can progress to cause destruction of genital tissue.
  • While there are similarities in the ulcer presentation between chancroid and donovanosis, the painful and suppurative inguinal bubo described in the case is more characteristic of chancroid.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a sexually active individual with painful genital sores, multiple painful bleeding ulcers, and a unilateral unilocular painful suppurative inguinal bubo, the most likely diagnosis is Chancroid.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 30 Page no 30.21

Online Resource: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/chancroid?source=search_result&search=chancroid&selectedTitle=1~47

questions.solution:

Explanation:

 

Colour Coding of Cylinders:

questions.text: A construction site manager is concerned about the potential risk of hearing damage to workers due to prolonged exposure to high levels of noise. He wants to implement safety measures to ensure that the noise levels at the site do not exceed the threshold at which substantial damage to hearing could occur. In this context, what is the maximum level of noise, measured in decibels (dB), at which a person can tolerate without any substantial damage to their hearing, provided the exposure duration is limited?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 90 dB

 

Explanation: 

 

Daily exposure up to 90 dB is the upper limit, people can tolerate without substantial damage to their hearing. (community) and 90 dB (Factory workers as per Factory Act, 1948)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sound Levels:

 

  • Human ear is sensitive to sound frequency: 20‚Äì20,000 Hz
  • Daily maximum tolerable sound level to human ear (without substantial damage to their hearing): 85-90 dB
  • Auditory fatigue appears in: 90 dB region (greatest at 4000 Hz) 
  • Sound level above which tympanic membrane rupture (permanent mechanical damage): 150-160 dB

 

Noise Levels

 

  • Whisper: 20-30 dB
  • Normal conversation: 60-70 dB
  • Mechanical damage: 150-160 dB (e.g Jet taking off).

 

Acceptable Noise Levels - expressed in dB (A), sound pressure levels conforming to the weighting curve (A)

 

Permissible noise levels in factories (Factory Act, 1948: 90 dB (8-hours workday) or 115 dB (15 minutes)

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 835.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Salter scale

 

Explanation:

 

Field instrument for weight measurement. It can weigh children upto 25 kg.

 

Birth Weight

 

Some important points -

 

  • Single best measure to assess physical growth: Weight
  • Birth weight preferably be measured within: 1st hour of life
  • Birth weight of an infant is the single most important determinant of its chances of survival, healthy growth and development
  • Average birth weight in India: 2.8 kg (2.7 ‚Äì 2.9 kg) 
  • Birth weight doubles at 5 months age, triples at 1 year and quadruples at 2 years age
  • Majority of LBW in India is due to Maternal malnutrition associated with fetal growth retardation
  • Relationship between maternal nutrition and birth weight of babies is Linear
  • Smoking during pregnancy reduces birth weight by an average by 170 grams
  • LBW is not a contraindication for any vaccination EXCEPT Hepatitis B. Hepatitis B vaccine is contraindicated in preterm children with birth weight <2.0 kg
  • Growth chart is plotted between Weight and Age

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Field instrument for weight measurement is Salter Scale

 

Reference: Park 26th edition (page 616)

questions.text: A symbol is displayed during a training session for medical staff. The staff are asked to identify the symbol. Which of the following does the displayed symbol denote?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Biohazard

 

Explanation:

 

THE BIOHAZARD SYMBOL:

 

  • An image that warns people of possible exposure to biological substances that are harmful to living organisms.
  • These biohazards can be viruses, toxins or medical waste.
  • Symbol was created by Charles Baldwin in 1966.

Reference: Park 26th ed pg. 888

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of persistent fatigue, lack of interest in daily activities, and difficulty concentrating. She mentions that these symptoms have affected her ability to work, maintain social relationships, and care for her children. Upon further inquiry, the physician learns that the patient has been experiencing feelings of worthlessness and has had frequent thoughts of death. The physician realizes that this condition is not only affecting this patient but is also a significant global health concern. What condition, which has become the largest single cause of disability worldwide, is this patient most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Depression

 

Option C:

 

Depression has been identified as a leading cause of disability worldwide by the World Health Organization. It affects individuals' ability to function in daily activities, impacting work productivity, social relationships, and overall quality of life. Depression's widespread prevalence and its profound impact on global health make it a significant concern for healthcare providers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiovascular diseases: While cardiovascular diseases are a leading cause of mortality globally, they do not typically present with symptoms like lack of interest, feelings of worthlessness, or thoughts of death.

 

Option B. Leprosy: Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease but is not a leading cause of global disability and does not match the patient's symptom profile.

 

Option D. Diabetes Mellitus: Diabetes is a major global health issue primarily affecting physical health. It typically does not manifest with the psychological symptoms described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Depression alone accounts for 4.3% of the global burden of disease and is among the largest single causes of disability worldwide (11% of all years lived with disability globally), particularly for women. It is MCC of DALY'S Lost among the Mental health disorders.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg. 927

questions.text: A Nuclear Physicist is giving a lecture on the historical events surrounding nuclear disasters. When discussing the infamous Chernobyl disaster, which occurred on April 26, 1986, he mentions that the catastrophe resulted in the largest reported emission of a specific radioactive material. Which of the following radioactive materials was predominantly released during this disaster?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. I-131, Cs-134, Cs-137, Sr-90

 

Explanation:

 

The accident at reactor 4 of the Chernobyl nuclear power station in the Soviet Union on April 26, 1986, in Russia (now Ukraine) is the largest reported accidental release of radioactive material in the history of nuclear power. It deposited more than 7 million curies of Iodine 131, Cesium 134 and 137, Strontium 90 and other isotopes throughout the northern hemisphere. It is the only instance so far of level 7 on the International Nuclear Event Scale for nuclear accidents. 

 

World’s worst man-made disaster is Bhopal gas Tragedy, 3rd December 1984

 

  • Methylisocyanate (MIC) gas leaked from Union Carbide pesticide plant in Bhopal, India. It resulted in resulting in the death of about 3,000 people according to the Indian Supreme Court. 

 

Fukushima Daichii Tragedy - 11 March 2011 - Released substance - I131, Cs134, Cs137.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chernobyl nuclear explosion accident occurred on 26th April, 1986. It resulted in emission of: I131, Cs134, Cs137, Sr90

 

Reference: Reference: Park 26th ed pg 890

questions.text: Dr. Sudhir, a healthcare quality improvement officer, is leading a team to set objectives for improving patient care at a hospital in New Delhi. He emphasizes the importance of setting SMART objectives to ensure that the goals are well-defined and achievable. Which of the following statements about SMART objectives is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. S- Sensitive

 

Option A: 

 

The correct attribute for 'S' in SMART is 'Specific,' which means the objective should be clearly defined and unambiguous.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Measurable: Correct. Objectives should be quantifiable or able to be measured to track progress.

 

Option C. Acceptable: Correct. While 'Acceptable' is correct, it also stands for 'Achievable' or 'Attainable,' meaning the objective should be realistically attainable given available resources.

 

Option D. Realistic:  Correct. Objective should be realistic and relevant to the mission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SMART objective - 

 

S-Specific

M-Measurable

A-Acceptable

R-Realistic

T-Time bound.

 

Ref: Textbook of Community medicine by Rajvir Balwar, 4th ed, pg. 1007

questions.text: Dr. Nandini, working in a rural health post in Maharashtra, India, is actively involved in community health programs. She often collaborates with local self-governing institutions to ensure effective healthcare delivery. During a recent community meeting, a discussion arose about the structure and functions of the Panchayati Raj system at the village level. Which of the following is NOT a part of the Panchayati Raj at the village level?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Panchayat Samiti


Explanation:

 

The Panchayati Raj is a 3-tier structure of rural local self-government in India, linking the village to the district. The three institutions are:

 

  1. Panchayat - at the village level.

  2. Panchayat Samiti - at the block level; and

  3. Zilla Parishad - at the district level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Panchayati Raj at the village level consists of:

 

  1. The Gram Sabha.

  2. The Gram Panchayat; and

  3. The Nyaya Panchayat.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed, pg. 975

questions.text: A 40-year-old health policy analyst from Hyderabad is invited to speak at an international conference about the evolution of healthcare systems around the world. During his presentation, he discusses the merits and challenges of socialized medicine, emphasizing how it can reduce competition among physicians and focus on patient care. He mentions the pioneering nation that first adopted this system, setting a precedent for many countries that followed. Which country was the first to socialize medicine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Russia

 

Explanation:

 

Russia was the first country to socialize medicine completely and to give its citizens a constitutional right to all health services.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Some firsts in Public Health:

 

  • First country to introduce Socialized medicine: Russia
  • First country to introduce Compulsory Sickness Insurance: Germany
  • First country to introduce Family Planning program: India
  • First country to introduce Blindness Control program: India
  • First country to introduce Fingerprint Bureau: India

 

Ref: Park 26th edition (page 10)

choices.text: Set less demanding Type I error.
Reduce variability of measurements (increased accuracy)
Use a one tailed test (directional alternate hypotheses)

questions.text: Dr. Alisha, a seasoned biostatistician, is supervising a group of researchers conducting a clinical trial on a new antihypertensive drug. The team is keen on reducing the possibility of a Type II error or beta error. In a team meeting, Dr. Alisha quizzes the group to test their understanding about reducing the chances of committing a Type II error. She asks, "Which of the following methods will not help in reducing the risk of a Type II error?"
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Decreasing the sample size.

 

Option A:

 

Decreasing the sample size is the method that will not help in reducing the risk of a Type II error. In fact, a smaller sample size usually increases the risk of a Type II error. A larger sample size generally provides more reliable data, enhancing the statistical power of a study and thereby reducing the likelihood of a Type II error, where a true effect is missed.

 

Type II Error:

 

  •  Null hypothesis is false but not rejected (or accepted)

  • Probability of Type II error is given by beta (b) (probability of declaring no significant difference when actually it is present)

  • Type I error is more serious than Type II error.‚Äì

 

            

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Setting a less demanding Type I error: Setting a higher threshold for Type I error (alpha) can sometimes help reduce the Type II error, as it allows for more flexibility in rejecting the null hypothesis.

 

Option C. Reducing variability of measurements (increased accuracy): Increased accuracy and reduced variability in measurements can enhance the study's power, thus decreasing the chance of a Type II error.

 

Option D. Using a one-tailed test (directional alternate hypotheses): One-tailed tests, which focus on detecting an effect in a specific direction, can be more powerful than two-tailed tests under certain conditions, thereby potentially reducing Type II error.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type II error or beta error can be reduced by the following ways.

 

  • Increase the sample size.

  • Set less demanding Type I error.

  • Reduce variability of measurements (increased accuracy)

  • Use a one tailed test (directional alternate hypotheses)

 

Ref: Essentials of Biostatistics- Indranil Saha- 2nd edition (page 89)

choices.text: Type I error
Type II error

questions.text: Dr. Kavya, a budding researcher, is going through the results of her recent clinical trial investigating a novel drug's efficacy for hypertension. She decides to compare her findings with the placebo group. Her senior, Dr. Varun, warns her about the potential pitfalls of statistical analyses and the importance of interpreting the p-value correctly. Specifically, he mentions a mistake that researchers might inadvertently make, leading to a claim of significant results when there are none. Which of the following best describes the error where a researcher rejects the null hypothesis when it is, in fact, true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Type I error

 

Option A:

 

Type I error or alpha error is the rejection of null hypothesis when it is true. Type I error is usually fixed in advance’ by the choice of level of significance employed in the test. Type I error is more serious than Type II error

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Type II error: This happens when the null hypothesis is not rejected when it is false, leading to a failure in identifying an effect that actually exists.

 

Option C. Power: The power of a test refers to the probability that it will correctly reject a false null hypothesis (i.e., detect an effect when there is one). 

 

Power of a test: 1 – b

 

  • The probability of rejecting a Null hypothesis when a predetermined clinically significant difference is indeed present.
  • Power can be increased by increasing the no. of subjects in a trial.

 

Option D. Specificity: In the context of diagnostic testing, specificity refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those without the disease (true negatives).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Null hypothesis true (in reality) but rejected (based on our study results) lead to Type I error.
  • Null hypothesis false (in reality) but accepted (based on our study results) lead to Type II error.

 

 

Ref: Essentials of Biostatistics- Indranil Saha- 2nd edition (page 88)

choices.text: It is Milky White in Colour.
It is an Emulsion with Egg Lecithin present in it.
It is considered the Best Agent for Day Care Surgery.
It is associated with High Incidence of Nausea and Vomiting.

questions.text: All are true about the drug shown in the image except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It is associated with High Incidence of Nausea and Vomiting.

 

Option D. It is associated with a high incidence of nausea and vomiting: This statement is not true. Propofol is known for its antiemetic properties and is often used to prevent nausea and vomiting during and after surgery.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option.

 

Option A. It is Milky White in Colour: This statement is true. Propofol is a milky white intravenous emulsion.

 

Option B. It is an Emulsion with Egg Lecithin present in it: This statement is true. Propofol is formulated as an emulsion that contains soybean oil, egg lecithin, and glycerol.

 

Option C. It is considered the Best Agent for Day Care Surgery: This statement is true. Propofol is often considered an excellent choice for day care or ambulatory surgeries due to its rapid onset and short duration of action, allowing for a quick recovery and discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol is commonly used in anesthesia due to its rapid onset of action, short duration, and antiemetic properties. Understanding its characteristics and benefits is important for anesthesia providers and healthcare practitioners.

 

 

REF: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anaesthesiology 7th edition page 336-340

questions.text: What is the Gold Standard for management of PDPH?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epidural Blood Patch

 

Option D. The Epidural Blood Patch is indeed the gold standard treatment for PDPH. It involves the injection of autologous blood into the epidural space to form a clot, which seals the dural puncture and stops CSF leakage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While rest is a part of the conservative management for postdural puncture headache (PDPH), it is not the gold standard treatment. Rest can help alleviate symptoms but does not address the underlying cause of the CSF leak.

 

Option B. Hydration is also a supportive measure to help with PDPH by potentially increasing CSF production, but it is not the definitive treatment for the condition.

 

Option C. Cerebral vasoconstriction ‚Äì caffeine and NSAIDs. These medications can provide symptomatic relief for PDPH by causing cerebral vasoconstriction and reducing pain. However, they are not considered the gold standard treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epidural blood patch is the gold standard for the management of postdural puncture headache, as it directly addresses the cause of the headache by sealing the dural puncture site and stopping CSF leakage.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail‚Äôs Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1850
